ygData.subject: Re: Picbreeder comments
ygData.msgSnippet: I agree with Peter and Jeff that it would be very difficult to learn what is interesting, even from a relatively good data set (like Picbreeder perhaps could

I agree with Peter and Jeff that it would be very difficult to learn 
what =
is interesting, even from a relatively good data set (like 
Picbreeder perh=
aps could provide).  The problem is that there are so 
many possible spurio=
us correlations between good pictures and other 
irrelevent factors that th=
e classifier will not get the deeper 
concept of what makes a good picture.=


Yet I agree with John in the sense that there is extremely rich and 
unus=
ual data in the Picbreeder database that may be useful for 
something beyon=
d Picbreeder itself.  I just think the right way to 
leverage it is tricky.=


The idea of complexity is also quite muddy.  Unfortunately, the word 
mea=
ns a lot of different things.  In fact, perhaps the best formal 
definition=
 ("minimal description length") is both proven 
uncomputable in general and=
 also does not correlate to what is meant 
by the normal intuitive use of t=
he word complexity with respect to 
evolution.  

As evolutionary complexit=
y goes up in the sense we usually mean it, 
it is not just that the phenoty=
pe takes more bits to describe.  
There is also a sense of organization, i.=
e. regularity, that begins 
to take hold.  That is in direct opposition wit=
h the idea of minimal 
description length.  In fact, what we really want is=
 some kind of 
partnership between complexity and organization.  Unfortunat=
ely that 
introduces yet another mysterious word: organization; it also 
in=
troduced a partnership between two seemingly opposing forces.  Yet 
I think=
 this muddiness and internal conflict is important because it 
shows that t=
his problem is extremely slippery.  It makes me wonder 
what is meant by "d=
oing well" for humans asked to select for 
complexity.

In any case, I do l=
ike the theme behind John's idea, but I think 
something more sophisitcated=
 needs to be done to capture the deeper 
reasons that certain pictures are =
selected.

ken

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Jeff Clune <jclune@...> wrote:=

>
> There have been experiments where people select for complexity (in 
an=

> information theory sense) instead of fitness...and it is reported 
that =
they
> do well. It would be interesting to see someone do that here, so 
yo=
u can see
> what (selected for) complexity looks like. But, aside from that=
 
curiosity, I
> doubt it could match humans in terms of producing things 
=
interesting to
> humans....
>

> > Evolving such a network (a netw=
ork that selects the parents for 
the
> > next generation) will be incredib=
ly hard. This is because there 
is
> > some intelligence required to perfor=
m a good selection. In TBE 
the
> > intelligence is the static fitness func=
tion, in Picbreeder it is 
the
> > human intelligence. In fact, some pictur=
es may be "in order" but
> > still represent nothing. Perhaps some pattern =
recognition 
technique
> > may be involved in the process, but this is stil=
l not enough.
> > But it is an interesting idea of NEAT controlling another=
 NEAT. A
> > population of "selector" networks, each one running an evoluti=
on.
> > This will take A LOT of CPU time, but it is good for 
experimenting=

> > with. 
> > 
> > Peter
> > 
> > --- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "John Arro=
wwood" <jarrowwx@> wrote:
> >> 
> >> Ken,
> >> 
> >> You had talked (at len=
gth...) about the merits of the human-
chooser
> >> verses the goal-oriente=
d evolution.  I'd like to weigh in on it 
a
> >> little and maybe throw in =
an idea for how to make things even 
more
> >> interesting...
> >> 
> >> Fi=
rst of all, there is always a goal.  In one case, the goal is 
very
> >> st=
rictly defined, in the other, it is more losely defined.  But
> > there
> >=
> is still a 'goal'.  The goal in PicBreeder is 'makes me feel 
good'
> >> =
which CAN be defined, it just has to be defined in terms of
> > something
>=
 >> we can't see, which is the neuron firing pattern in our brains.
> >> 
>=
 >> My hypothesis, though, is that there is a pattern to our 
internal
> >>=
 choosing of what we like.  And I posit that it may be possible 
to
> >> LE=
ARN it.  Meaning, create a 'chooser' network that also evolves
> >> 'intere=
sting' images.
> >> 
> >> You see, I think that 'recognition' is a key elem=
ent in deciding
> > what
> >> to choose.  And I think that the method that =
we use to recognize
> > order
> >> vs. chaos could be modeled.  Sure, recog=
nizing the difference
> > between
> >> two people's faces would be harder t=
o model, but I think it 
would be
> >> fairly easy to learn to model the di=
fference between chaos and
> > order.
> >> 
> >> I'm thinking you should be=
 able to evolve a network that tends 
to
> >> choose (rank higher) images o=
f real-world things over images of
> >> random, unstructured noise.  You co=
uld take many image chunks 
the
> > size
> >> of the PicBreeder output imag=
es, all of which have some kind of
> >> recognizability and pleasantness to=
 them.  Then create a large
> > number
> >> of counter-examples that are bu=
ilt out of unstructured 
randomness,
> > be
> >> it pixels or blobs or arcs=
 or whatever.  Then evolve a network 
that
> >> consistently recognizes the=
 'pleasing' images (ranks them 
highly)
> > and
> >> recognizes the chaotic=
 images as such and thereby ranks them 
lower.
> >> 
> >> When that's done,=
 integrate it into the PicBreeder app as
> > a 'chooser'
> >> which evolves=
 and evolves until somebody shuts it down.  
Whenever it
> >> finds somethi=
ng that it likes more than some threshold, 
it 'saves'
> > it.
> >>  When i=
t likes something more than an even higher threshold, it
> >> publishes it.=

> >> 
> >> I predict that there will be a sweet spot for complexity of the=

> >> PicBreeder image generating networks.  For a while, as 
complexity
> =
>> grows, the chooser network will rank the images higher and 
higher.
> >>=
 But I suspect that at some point, that trend will reverse.  The
> > number=

> >> of highly ranked images as a percentage of all evolved images 
at a
>=
 >> particular complexity level will get lower as the complexity 
rises
> >=
> above that sweet spot.
> >> 
> >> I would also like to mention that combi=
ning such a 'general 
coolness
> >> chooser' with a goal-oriented chooser c=
ould be quite 
interesting.
> > The
> >> two could work together synergisti=
cally to help walk the search
> > space
> >> faster.  Problem may be to gen=
erate that chooser correctly to 
begin
> >> with.  But my instincts tell me=
 that one that is evolved to find
> >> regularity in an image and finds 'pl=
easing' relationships 
between
> >> them, such as the one described above, =
would be adequate to use 
in
> >> conjunction with a goal-oriented evolutio=
n of the CPPN networks 
for
> >> who-knows-what.  The reason I say that is =
that I suspect that 
the
> > same
> >> 'regularities' that make for a 'plea=
sing' image are the same
> >> characteristics that lead to a functional CPP=
N network.  But I'm
> > sure
> >> you would know better based on your exper=
iences working with 
them.
> >> 
> >> Just thought I'd throw that out there=
 for you to think about.
